heading: schwab down for the count
subheading: the leading online broker is caught with its systems down for over two hours. the company says it will offer investors after-hours trading later in the day.
author: reuters
text: charles schwab corp., the no. 1 us online broker, said wednesday a system failure just as stock markets were opening prevented its customers from trading stocks by computer for more than two hours. schwab added that it fixed the problem and would go ahead with plans to offer its investors after-hours trading for the first time later in the day.part of the broker's system went down at 9:30 a.m. edt, preventing investors from placing orders through its web site, a spokeswoman said, adding that its automated, touch-tone phone system also suffered intermittent problems."we don't know how many (customers) were affected," she told reuters. customers were still able to place orders by calling a phone representative or by visiting one of the broker's branch offices, she said. they were also apparently able to view information such as stock quotes and account balances on the web site, she added.online brokers have suffered crashes on occasion as they have upgraded their systems in their struggle to handle the growing number of trades made by individual investors. td waterhouse group inc. had similar problems last month when the system that routes its orders had technical difficulties.schwab processed 175,400 trades a day in the third quarter, compared with 141,900 for the same period last year. but it handled fewer than the 200,000-plus recorded in the first two quarters of 1999.the spokeswoman said the broker would conduct its first after-hours trading session between 4:30 p.m. edt and 7 p.m. edt on wednesday. investors would be able to trade in most stocks listed on the nasdaq market as well as some from the new york stock exchange, according to a company statement."although schwab's after hours trading session officially opens at 4:30 p.m., customers can begin placing limit orders for the after hours session at 4:05 p.m. until 7:00 p.m. (edt)," it said. "the maximum order size will be 5,000 shares (100 share minimum)."schwab is the latest online broker to offer after-hours trading in an effort to meet growing demand from individual investors to trade whenever they want.charles schwab's stock was off 3/16 at 29-1/4 in early afternoon trading on the new york stock exchange.copyright* 1999 reuters limited.*
